concept.title: elements within re-use topics
concept.shortdesc:
You should use logical, identifiable id attributes. Short phrase-level elements intended for re-use can be
into tables for ease of maintenance.

conbody.p:
Easy-to-identify id attributes should be used for re-use elements. In choosing names, you should prefix the id values to indicate the purpose of the element, such as:
var_
for short re-use phrases and variables
term_
for terms and definitions
step_
for task steps
warning_
for warning notes
fig_
for figures

To provide a reference for how re-use elements are meant to be used, you may choose to
re-use phrases (or variables) into tables, where a description of the element's intended use can be documented alongside the re-use content.

lq.reftitle: JoAnn Hackos, Yahoo DITA Users Group
lq.p: We're quite scrupulous in promoting the best practice of linking by conref to content that has been moved out of its original context and into a separate file or collection file.

As a result, the ownership of the referenced content is well-established and changes are better controlled and monitored. The danger to using conrefs to embedded content is changes to that content that are largely uncontrolled. This practice also ensures that the translation of the content is controlled as a reusable element rather than being translated in context in its "home" location.

When a block of content is identified for reuse through conrefs, we suggest that the author or architect remove the content from the "home" location and create new file in a "common" folder or defined location. The file may contain only a single block of content or may contain more than one related content blocks. For example, we might group all the Dangers in a common file so that they are easier to maintain and find.
This practice seems to keep everything well organized. It also is supported by the Best Practice for conrefs that has been developed by the OASIS DITA Translation Subcommittee.
